p: Anxiety in relation to the virus showed a significant increase over the three measurement dates ( F(1.47,2374.32) = 2386.04, p < .001, η p 2 = .60), both from December 2019 to January 2020 ( t(1614) = |27.85|, p < .001, d = 0.59) and especially strong from January 2020 to March 2020 ( t(1614) = |46.14|, p < .001, d = 1.16; the anxiety in December 2019 and January 2020 was assessed retrospectively). About half of the respondents stated that they suffer from moderate to severe anxiety associated with SARS-CoV-2 at the current time (March 2020), with about 25 % of the respondents choosing a score between 50–75 and about 25 % a score between 75 and 100 (0–100, 100 = very severe anxiety).
